discourse_list.title: [Signal Request] REPEAL Poll ID-827 Deployment of a Permissionless Open Market Operation Trial

content.content: In an effort to be certain that Poll ID 827 Trial Deployment of a Permissionless Open Market Operation should move forward to an Executive Vote, I have constructed this Signal Request that allows Level 2 Community Members to REPEAL Poll ID 827. This Signal Request will run until Monday, June 27, 2022 and end at 21:00 UTC.  Background The Signal Request titled “Deploy a Trial Permissionless Open Market Operation & Resurrect the Burn” was published on Thursday, May 26, 2022. It proposed to MKR token owners if the DssKiln Module should be used to run a 3-month trial of repurchasing MKR in the open market. These are the proposed parameters:  3M DAI will be vested from the Surplus Buffer to the deployed contract for the duration of 3 months This configuration would result in roughly 33.33k DAI  being burned daily (limited by the vesting schedule) Includes further development and financing of the formal audit of DssKiln which will be paid by PECU form their existing budget. The Oversight Group will consist of Risk CU and Protocol Engineering CU, performance reporting will be conducted no less than on a monthly basis. General operation parameters   sell the token to be deposited into DssKiln and sold - [DAI]  buy the token to be bought in exchange for the sold token - [MKR]  hop duration specified in seconds. It represents a minimum number of seconds that must pass before the lot can be sold - [38880 seconds or 10.8 hours]  lot the maximum quantity of tokens to be sold per hop - [30k DAI]   Specific operation parameters: to be published by Risk CU and Protocol Engineering CU once the code required is fully developed and all operation-specific parameters are defined.   The Outcome of the Signal Request and on-chain Poll ID: 827 Signal Request:  ” Do you support the proposed solution explained above, including (i) proposed operation methodology (ii) Proposed General & Specific (to be decided by Risk CU and PECU) DssKiln operation parameters, (iii) financing and further required development of DssKiln formal audit with the surplus buffer facilitated by PECU?”  44% Yes ballots 33% Abstain ballots 23% No ballots  On-chain Poll ID 827 Results: ” Deploy a Trial Permissionless Open Market Operation - June 13, 2022”  47,724 MKR Voted Yes  9,054 MKR Voted No  6,000 MKR Voted Abstain    Motivating Community Reasons To Repeal  We currently have MKR token owners that believe the Signal Request and on-chain Vote was rushed, and MIP74 has yet to be enacted. We have some MKR token owners who believe this proposal “sneaked in through the cracks”, and MKR token owners and Delegates need to be more diligent. When this Signal Request was made, the Maker Community was not properly informed that it could possibly be exposed to Counterparty Risk (Celsius, Nexo, etc.) and it should be preserving Cash, not burning. Some MKR token owners believe that burning MKR during a down-cycle is unconventional and MakerDAO should be saving every Conti, every DAI earned during a turbulent cycle.  Shadow Delegate 0x749 was not able to vote as they were in the middle of setting up their Delegate Platform, and re-delegating their self-owned MKR.  Recognized Delegate @Hasu was on vacation, as @GovAlpha-Core-Unit and @Recognized-Delegates have yet to design an alternative plan for taking time-off from Delegate Voting. We have MKR token Owners who prefer a Burn at a much lower daily capacity  and duration (Perhaps less DAI over the next 3-months, or 12-months?)  This trial along with MIP74 can be opine by some as an initiative for expanding the scope of the Maker Core into becoming an “active trader” assuming MIP74 is enacted.   Signal Request Poll    REPEAL Poll ID 827 Deploy a Trial Permissionless Open Market Operation  Yes No Abstain     0 voters     This Signal Request will run until Monday, June 27, 2022 and end at 21:00 UTC. Full Disclosure: 3F Delegate Voted No to Poll ID 827 and Yes to MIP74

content.content: @flipflopflapdelegate thank you for posting this Signal. The following is a summary of the governance impacts of this proposal from GovAlpha’s perspective, in the interests of providing clarity around this proposal:  This is a valid Signal Request, although the duration could perhaps be a bit longer, I don’t think that should invalidate this proposal. This Signal seeks to repeal this vote in its entirety. As currently written, this includes the approval for auditing and deploying DssKiln as well as the proposed burn of 3 million DAI. If approved by > 50% of non-abstain votes, this proposal will be eligible for an on-chain poll on 2022-07-04, which will run for three days. This will be a binary poll with Yes, No, and Abstain as the only options. If the on-chain poll is successful, GovAlpha will not permit the previously approved proposal to proceed to an executive vote. I have assigned this a high-impact tag as it seeks to override a previously approved on-chain vote. As it has been posted by a Recognized Delegate, this proposal is eligible for off-chain incentives if approved by Maker Governance.   Tagging relevant actors that this proposal affects for visibility (this is a non-exhaustive list, please tag other people who you think may be interested or affected by this proposal): @GovAlpha-Core-Unit @Risk-Core-Unit @Protocol-Engineering @rune @Recognized-Delegates @strat-fin-core-unit @aburban90

content.content: I voted no. This will set a terrible precedent opening any and all goverance to go through n-number of polls. Should this poll pass, the natural next step for those in favor of the original proposal will be to make a new SR to repeal the repeal. In fact what is stopping anyone from doing that even before this SR is concluded? I hope the community can see how quickly this becomes silly. There was nothing in this proposal to put it apart from other proposals, neither were there less time or more proposals than at other times in governance. This is just another oportunistic stab by those that do not agree that the burn should ever be back on the table. If a single week is all it takes to change direction I feel sorry for Governance that will have to deal with repeating SRs every week going forward. As to the motivations that are listed:     flipflopflapdelegate:  We currently have MKR token owners that believe the Signal Request and on-chain Vote was rushed, and MIP74 has yet to be enacted.   This proposal has been on the forum for weeks before going on-chain giving ample time to give feedback for anyone interested.     flipflopflapdelegate:  We have some MKR token owners who believe this proposal “sneaked in through the cracks”, and MKR token owners and Delegates need to be more diligent.   There is nothing special in this proposal compared to other proposals in this regard. Delegates are all required to be diligent through the code of conduct.     flipflopflapdelegate:  When this Signal Request was made, the Maker Community was not properly informed that it could possibly be exposed to Counterparty Risk (Celsius, Nexo, etc.) and it should be preserving Cash, not burning.   How on earth is it possible to be confused about the intention of the proposal when it litterally has “ressurect the burn” in its title?     flipflopflapdelegate:  Shadow Delegate 0x749 was not able to vote as they were in the middle of setting up their Delegate Platform, and re-delegating their self-owned MKR.   Yet somehow the same shadow delegate was able to vote on other polls.     flipflopflapdelegate:  Recognized Delegate @Hasu was on vacation, as @GovAlpha-Core-Unit and @Recognized-Delegates have yet to design an alternative plan for taking time-off from Delegate Voting.   This really opens a can of worms. I’m on vacation right now yet I still find a way to monitor what is going on. On the other hand I guess I better start a SR to repeal all votes that went through on Monday since I was on vacation and Gov-Alpha didn’t do my work for me.     flipflopflapdelegate:  We have MKR token Owners who prefer a Burn at a much lower daily capacity and duration (Perhaps less DAI over the next 3-months, or 12-months?)   This can easily be handled by doing a SR to change the parameters for a long er duration. The proposal is set to last for 3 months. Hardly an urgent matter. And it would be much more in line with how we usually modify proposals.     flipflopflapdelegate:  This trial along with MIP74 can be opine by some as an initiative for expanding the scope of the Maker Core into becoming an “active trader” assuming MIP74 is enacted.   These concerns were known at the time of voting.

content.content: flipflopflapdelegate:  Motivating Community Reasons To Repeal  We have some MKR token owners who believe this proposal “sneaked in through the cracks”, and MKR token owners and Delegates need to be more diligent. When this Signal Request was made, the Maker Community was not properly informed that it could possibly be exposed to Counterparty Risk (Celsius, Nexo, etc.) and it should be preserving Cash, not burning. Some MKR token owners believe that burning MKR during a down-cycle is unconventional and MakerDAO should be saving every Conti, every DAI earned during a turbulent cycle.    While I am reasonably ambivalent about the substance of the deployment, it does seem like there are some pretty serious procedural issues that could be pointed out here. None of the above points seem like legitimate reasons to repeal the earlier vote and they could set a tricky precedent. (Edit: I see @JustinCase has posted at the same time and made similar arguments: I agree with his comments).   Anyone who disagrees with a particular vote could opine that “MKR tokenholders need to be more diligent” - given that the earlier vote was procedurally sound, this reason could be supplied for essentially any governance decision.   I’m not sure what you mean @flipflopflapdelegate by the statement that the “the Maker Community was not properly informed” and that “it should be preserving cash, not burning”. While I’ve been vocal in advocating for some of the arguments against the burn in the past, isn’t the decision to burn rather than preserve cash a legitimate decision for the community to make? There isn’t an ‘objective’ correct answer.   Yes, while some MKR tokenholders believe that burning MKR during a down-cycle is unconventional, many others think that it should be a priority for the protocol - and the letter group won the earlier vote! Again, this argument could be made to roll back any governance decision, just by saying “well, another group of MKR holders thinks differently.”   If a large MKR whale wants to overturn an earlier decision, per @Patrick_J’s post that’s a perfectly legitimate governance option. But let’s not pretend that there are many other  “community reasons to repeal”, especially if those risk setting a precedent for future governance decisions to be overturned in a laissez-faire manner.

content.content: Voted No for a number of reasons.  The time and place to kill this was in the polling stage.  If you don’t read and understand the implications of a poll don’t vote YES plain and simple. Mixed on precedent here because at any time another signal request can be put forward which can change anything. This isn’t an emergency because even if enacted it would have been buying 33K DAI worth of MKR a day  Personally I would like to adjust the conditions on the buyback (like this only buys if the MKR price is below a certain $$/MKR) and to reconsider whether to formally burn vs. just taking the MKR and putting it up with the remaining DAI in a MKR-DAI v3 position once say about 1.5M of the DAI has purchased MKR.    But that is about all I would want to change at this point. Goal here is to at least try and test such a mechanism and if governance wants to revisit this simply do a NEW poll not a poll to REPEAL a previously passed one.   Like if this was an executed executive that would be the correct path forward.  Maker governance for all its good or ills always MOVES forward and overwrites old proposals with new ones.   Make a new signal request regarding pausing the buying here and/or returning the funds but repealing a previously passed proposal sorry am a NO here just on principle and process. Now if this was some sort of emergency well then doing an emergency poll and executive would be reasonable.

content.content: Hasu:  Why is 50% of forum votes necessary for the vote to move on-chain when it’s clear that it would pass with MKR majority?   Signals must pass at the forum polling stage before proceeding to an on-chain vote. Therefore, this proposal requires >50% of non-abstain votes to move on-chain. This is a long-standing precedent at MakerDAO. This allows greater speed in the Governance process but requires community approval as a trade-off. Re: Sybil resistance, we monitor Signal Requests for signs of Sybil attacks and will intervene when necessary. This is also aided by restricting Signals to trust_level_2 forum members, this prevents new accounts from being created to brigade Signals such as this. Note that GovAlpha did not post this proposal and weren’t consulted before it was posted, we are responding to the proposal as written to inform voters. We can discuss non-signal alternatives if requested/required. @MakerMan GovAlpha would be delighted to discuss alternative options if asked - after all, our mandate requires us to seek to build consensus. In fact, we were slightly disappointed that nobody attended our office hours yesterday to discuss this very issue. The above posts are neither an endorsement nor a rebuttal of this proposal. It describes our response to the SR as posted. If the author of the proposal wants to solicit feedback and make changes, that is up to them.

content.content: In many other DAOs, the largest whale tokenholders ignore governance until a vote passes that they do not like. They then use their vast voting power to simply come in and reverse the undesirable decision. They let the minnows play in the governance pool and think that they have some control… until something happens that goes against their interests and they storm into the room and hit the abort button. I am not saying that this is what happened here. But I am saying that this SR would ultimately support this type of bad behavior here in MakerDAO. That’s why I’ve voted against. I support mechanisms to keep delegates more informed & to give them ample time to vote in advance in case they take time off, etc.  But I don’t support reversing decisions that have already been codified UNLESS new, material info comes to light that significantly alters the context of the original poll/vote. Follow the rules. If you don’t like the rules, work to change the rules. Don’t try to rewrite history. Look forward only when it come to the rails that governance rides on.

content.content: Patrick_J:  Signals must pass at the forum polling stage before proceeding to an on-chain vote. Therefore, this proposal requires >50% of non-abstain votes to move on-chain. This is a long-standing precedent at MakerDAO. This allows greater speed in the Governance process but requires community approval as a trade-off.   Seems worthwhile to point to the MIPs and Monthly Governance Cycle at this point in the thread. There is a method for bringing an item to vote without having to poll community sentiment. It takes longer and is more cumbersome to make up for the fact that you do not need to reach any form of consensus to have it go onchain. Also seems worth mentioning that we create and maintain these systems to make sure the “front door” to governance remains as accessible as possible. At the end of the day, the protocol is a series of smart contracts, it requires no governance process for new spells to be submitted. What we are building here is a social layer to make sure MKR holders can be informed about votes and their repercussions before being asked to place their MKR in support. Always up for jamming on new governance designs, but having a fast track to the voting portal that is not based on MKR weight is pretty important for the community. By allowing ideas to be debated and considered before they are voted on we give the chance to inspire true DAO work, the ability to build something permissionlessly and see if the community would like to incorporate it. This is a huge positive for the community, even if it does lead to occasionally skirmishes like this.

Getting them all to level 5 and voting with them whatever way they desire?   The time commitment and the knowledge that forum admins can undo their work in a snap of a finger. Like this is a thing people could do but it’s a pretty useless investment of time. For one, you would have no power to get these things passed on chain, so your organization is only effective for blocking votes. Then on the blocking side you’d have to use a whole bunch of the same accounts to vote no on all the signals you dislike, creating a pretty obvious way to catch the bad action and delete the work that went into it.

content.content: While I haven’t been around when the Signal Request → On-chain Poll flow was designed, I am pretty sure its objective function was to prevent spam proposals from going into the voting stage. In other words, it is only for blocking proposals that are clearly NOT in the best interest of MKR holders. The goal was certainly not to enshrine forum accounts into governance. As a result, it seems clear to me that SR quorums shouldn’t be used to block proposals that MKR holders clearly want to go on-chain. That would be an abuse of the process. Just send the thing to voting.     prose11:  Seems worthwhile to point to the MIPs and Monthly Governance Cycle at this point in the thread. content.content: Hasu:  I am pretty sure its objective function was to prevent spam proposals from going into the voting stage   This is one purpose but it goes deeper. Having these polls encourages discussion and debate so we can uncover the issues with potential changes before they are put up to vote. Doesn’t always work, but adds a layer of protection to large MKR holders thinking something is a good idea and going straight to onchain polling with it. In the signal route, we have a short timeframe but with heavily contested points of view and public votes for encouraging discussions and deeper discourse. With MIPs, it’s a longer process so that people have time to comment on it before going to vote.
